title: I hope a support update comes after the fighter update
body:
We see people complaining about the stale meta in many other lanes, and now attention is being driven to it
So just how stale is support?

Well for starters, Thresh has dominated the pick percentage ever since his conception 2 damn years ago
for the last 2 years we have been stuck in the "tanky support only" where tanky champions start to flood the support role even though it isn't their intended role, much like APC's did, though I will say that we have been seeing more high based utility supports being played currently like Janna and Nami but being honest both these champions have always been decent picks, and peel is helpful

Support champions who are gated by needing AP (Sona/Soraka/Karma) have a really shitty selection of 50AP or less items what cost 2k+ to stave their hilariously low utility ratios, if you want a support who deals damage and has utility, just pick Annie/Brand/Velkoz/Morgana and not be gated by the requirement of needing 250+ap to do anything, insultingly almost all these AP support items have their major active compenent being "Attach yourself to an allied champion and make them deal more damage" what is a nice concept and all, but please dont apply it to the most stat hungry role (these should be mana/regen/cdr items)

Sightstone in general needs to be updated, the items stats are uncalled for 2/3rds of the support cast, it delays fun interation and is the only damn reason why people in other roles don't bother with warding (because the support should do it all, right?)

Can we please change this meta where you are expected to be a innately tanky champion and the vision bitch into something what actually gets the half of the support cast who never see the light of day, to finally be involved
2 year's of the same thing is a long time of morbidity...please?

Riot tried that at the end of season 3, we got something called "utility scaling" which was so dreadful that Riot has since removed it from almost every support they put it on. On paper, it was a good idea: Support champs have their utility scale. Stuns become longer, slows become more powerful, movement speed boosts have a longer duration, heals get stronger, etc.

The problem came from two issues:

1) Utility scaled with AP, which is something support itemization even today can have a lot of trouble with. Getting 200 AP on a support can be a challenge sometimes.

2) Riot was afraid to let utility be powerful. The scaling started out very weak and wasn't able to scale up to anything impressive even with massive amounts of AP. We imagined {{champion:117}} turning allies into the Flash, {{champion:26}} basically slowing people into a snare for an ungodly duration, {{champion:44}} auras giving entire teams thousands of gold worth of stats, etc. Instead, what we got was underwhelming and not much more powerful utility than before the scaling was introduced.

"Hey guys, you know how you have a 40% slow on your support champ? Well now with utility scaling you can have a 45% slow! If you build 250 AP. And the slow starts off at 15% and only increases with AP. And you'll most likely only reach this AP total right before the game ends. Doesn't that sound like a buff to you?" - Riot Games circa Post-Season 3, Pre-Season 4.

I think the problem with utility ratios is far more general than that.  Traditional supports are a class meant to operate on low gold - this is why they're focused around buffs and peels that remain relevant because the person you cast them for is able to scale with items.  For these champions to have fair powercurves, this also requires their spells to otherwise scale less than others' spells.  This is why Riot was nerfing solo lane supports for a long time - because they don't want those champions to have the best of both worlds, and that's fair.

The issue becomes when Riot tries to achieve a support "fantasy" by pushing more gold into the role.  Now this low-gold niche of traditional supports is gone, and you see champions who scale better with gold become more competitive options.  Utility ratios were Riot's answer to this, but forcing supports to build AP to access these makes them build like a mage support, someone who will still use that AP better than the support unless the support has amazing ratios, which brings us back to the problem in the first paragraph.  

There's any number of alternate solutions Riot could've pursued, but the core problem is that they tried to push gold onto a class that was intended to operate with low gold.

That's **because** of Leona/Thresh/Nautilus/Alistar. When tanky all in supports thrive, she thrives as well. 

Switch the meta over to sustain/poke and you won't see her nearly as much.

What supports need:
1. More gp/5 starting or ending itemization - mana/ad/armor/mr
2. Specialized trinkets for supports (when you buy a gp/5 iitem it unlocks special trinkets like moving wards, objectives all get lit up on map, gives vision on all enemies x amount from you, ghost trinket, unkillable pink wards)
3. more utility items that build from gp/5. like targons + giant's belt that gives and active where you can drop a health pack or spellthief + recurve bow where you get gold stacks for harassing enemies and can spend an active to give allies gold.

I think a really big part of this is relic shield too.  Normally when people set up the rock/paper/scissors of support it's all-in beats sustain, sustain beats poke, poke beats all-in.  However, by giving the all-in gp10 (relic) a proc that provides sustain, it's helping all-in to beat their intended counter:  poke.  Just look at how popular poke supports are right now - not at all.  They get beaten by the sustain/shield supports and they aren't strong enough to actually beat the all-in supports.  That, along with lifesteal, makes it incredibly hard for poke supports to actually do their jobs, and is why we end up at Thresh/Leona/Morgana as the big 3 supports season in and season out.

But, I also agree - utility ratios were a joke & traditional supports still have some catching up to do to compete with mage supports in a meta where AP purchases are expected on support.  This was the problem in S3, and I imagine it'll still be a problem if Thresh/Leona/Morgana are ever dislodged from atop the support class (for an appreciable amount of time).

I really hate playing as Soraka and not knowing what the hell to build after my essentials because there's nothing helpful and I have no idea what I am. Am I a tank? Am I a healer? Am I doing damage? What the hell am I doing here? Why am I playing Soraka? There are items with utility passives, but what if I don't want those stats?

Resistances, AP, and CDR is what you want. Don't focus on health or health regen because of how her W works, ever since the regen rework, it's based on percentages of your base regen, and Soraka's base regen is so god fucking awful that buying any just isn't worth it. Unfortunately the items she loves the most are rather expensive for a support ({{item:3157}} {{item:3060}})

Tanks basically have the cheapest builds in the game while simultaneously being the least item/feed dependent. Hence why so many supports are tanks. You  couldn't even spend the kind of money assassins and ADCs have to spend on items if you wanted to.

Adc hasn't been touched even longer and the role is kind of a mess right now. I want to see changes to IE PD and remove the crit RNG behind them and also the power that makes it impossible to buy anything else. Itemizing is pretty stale. The crit bullshit needs to be addressed if nothing else.

champion viability in ADC is NEVER stale, the Meta shifts of everyone else dictates who is good and who is bad in adc. Are tanks weaker? grab high burst adc's like graves/lucian/corki/ezreal they'll wreck everyones face. Are assassins so plentiful you can't walk two steps out of lane without three ambushing you? pick an adc with great escape potential like Ezreal/caitlyn/tristana. Are games generally longer because of low push potential? pick a hyper carry like vayne/jinx/kog'maw.

And so on and so forth. ADC itemization is actually probably the most versatile of all itemization builds, it's the rest of the meta that determines which items have the highest kill potential for an adc so most of the time it's a moot point.

Compared to Support ADC is fine. When you literally only see 2 to three champs every game for support because there is absolutely no one better for that role, you know you have a huge issue. the Tanky meta and it's two major counters is a horrible position to be in. when you have to play support you should be able to be flexible with your picks to make better team comps but since tanky supports have just as much (if not more in so many cases) utility as a utility support you know something is wrong. The best example I can see is Sona vs braum/leona where they have more utility than the actual utility support, AND they both literally outscale the crap out of her. Usually when I play sona support I go "fuck it I'll grab luden's/lich/archangel's and one shot the adc. that way even if I have less impact on a teamfight than the leona or braum I did get that bitch down." (pardon my language) it points to really poor balancing when one champion can have more impact than another with a kit that does virtually the same thing.

Only 3 supports? Which of Alistair, Soraka, Braum, Janna, thresh, Leona, Nami, Annie, and Nautilus are not playable in your opinion. You mention Sona, but she is one of the weakest support champs, "arguably". I say arguably because I play her and I think even she isn't as bad as people say. If the enemy isn't playing a strong gank jungler like Lee sin she's a very good lane bully. If she's the worst support out of a dozen the role is in a good position.

I'm not talking about picks anyway, I'm talking about items, which you didn't provide a counter argument for. For almost every adc you go IE into PD into LW every game. Sometimes you can be greedy and choose Bloodthirster 3rd instead of LW. That's the extent of depth that goes into buying items. It's the most stale of any role.

And even if you don't agree with the above, you can't possibly argue that crit RNG is healthy design. It's extremely tilting to lose against another adc just because he got more crits than you did.

soraka, alistar, nami, and Braum are rare picks for a reason. There's someone that can do what they can do but better. Nami is one that I personally love but realized very quickly that her kit is simply too lackluster. Everything it does can just be done much better by leona/thresh (these two are part of the current trio, the last spot is usually janna, though morg may appear in rare instances to counter the either of the two it's really just which of the two is fotm against tank meta). naut is one that I neglected to mention as I only see him rarely as a support because he's still picked as a jungler in my division.

As for items, IE was gutted in S3, it's not a end all be all item anymore. If your adc can capitalize better with attack speed, you rush BORK, Bloodthirster isn't what it used to be, but if you need the extra health (and heavy assassin meta's basically necessitate this kind of build) it's a good damage alternative. Any AD caster type benefits from blue build for poking down champs. It really comes down to how your ADC is doing it's job in the current game. synergy only goes so far when building a champ, and sometimes you need to bite the bullet and just build BORK to shred tanks or build IE to two-three shot squishies because that's how the game is going.

I will admit that Crit RNG is awful, though I think that ashe provides some great insight to how Crit could work. make it simply a reliable damage multiplier that can only be obtained through glass cannon items, and voila RNG removed, and damage gets equalized across the board. Though this is only a theory and could radically change the meta across the board in unintended ways. Biggest issue is that everything is balanced around the ADC and while itemization is fairly stale it's mostly because they have the least dynamic role. They only have one job, deal damage. How they accomplish it is mostly up to their kit and not really items.

i think someone pointed this out, but supports have (kinda) gotten 2 updates already, one with the "utility scaling", the other being Shurelya's attempt to help them out way back when.  the utility scaling never really went any where, as for Shurelya's update, while it might not have much of an impact on the game any more, i think it proved that many people really have no idea how to balance.

Oh gosh. I just wish you could play season 1 and 2 support. You think you're the only one warding now? There used to be no sightstone and no limit on how many wards you personally could put on the map. e.g. 90% of your job was to just keep buying individual wards and putting them down. Like you would have to buy at least 5 every time you went b. Sometimes you would have multiple stacks of wards. 

The only gold boost items had flat gold gain, pickpocket didn't exist, and the useful actives were on items like Shurelia's Reverie, which had no offensive stats. Also getting AP was waaay harder, because there was maybe one useful support item with AP on it (old WotA, though some people would still flame you for buying it...). 

Truly this is something that they have been working on forever, and they've made a TON of progress in this field (you think champ picks aren't diverse now? Back in the day it was {{champion:16}} v. {{champion:37}} every single goddamn match.). Personally, I would much rather have "non-support champions" taking on the support role than having it relegated to only 2 or 3.
